questions.text: A 12 year old child presents with recurrent episodes of colicky abdominal pain for the preceding three months and blood in stool. The abdominal and other systemic examination was non-contributory. Complete hemogram, routine biochemical panels, and ultrasonography of the abdomen were normal. Stool for occult blood was negative. Following picture is shown on examination, what is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Peutz-Jeghers Syndrome is a rare autosomal dominant disorder (incidence: ~1 : 120,000 total population) characterized by mucocutaneous pigmentation and extensive GI hamartomatous polyposis. Mucocutaneous pigmentary changes of PJS usually appear during early infancy and scattered over the lips, buccal mucosa, perioral and perianal areas, fingers, feet, and less commonly over the gums and palate.

Differentials of the oral pigmentation :

  • Laugier-Hunziker syndrome (PJS like muco-cutaneous changes, pigmented nail streaks, no visceral involvement),
  • Addison's disease (pigmentation of the oral mucosa, skin creases and pressure points, fatigue, postural hypotension),
  • Carney complex (associated with blue nevus and pigmentary schwannomas, myxomas of skin and heart),
  • oral melanocytic nevus (gray-brown or black lesion, located over hard palate and buccal mucosa, common in females and in old age),
  • resolving oral lichen planus (usually associated with cutaneous lesions of lichen planus).

Other options:

  1. Intussusception has an acute onset and presents with abdominal pain, vomiting and bloody stools. USG shows intestine coiled within itself, which looks like a bull's eye. No pigmentation seen.
  2. Intestinal lymphangiectasia causes swelling, thickening of small intestine wall and fluid in the small intestine wall and fluid in abdomen and lungs. It can also cause enlarged lymph vessels in the small intestine. A flexible scope and tissue samples are used to diagnose intestinal lymphangiectasia.
  3. Celiac disease is caused by gluten hypersensitivity presenting gradually as abdominal pain, diarrhea, weight loss and sometimes rash. It has a chronic course.

Reference: Nelson textbook of Pediatrics, 22nd edition, Chapter 393, Page number:2411

questions.text: All of the following are the causes of continuous murmur except -
questions.solution:
A continuous murmur is a murmur that continues from systole into diastole and indicates continuous flow, such as in the presence of a PDA or other aortopulmonary communication.

Options A.,B.,D. are causes of continuous murmur.

This murmur should be differentiated from a to-and- fro murmur, where the systolic component of the murmur ends at or before S2 and the diastolic murmur begins after S2 with semilunar valve closure (aortic stenosis and insufficiency; pulmonary stenosis and insufficiency).

Reference: Nelson textbook of Pediatrics, 22nd edition, Chapter-471, Page number- 2743

questions.text: Which among the following is not seen during a Tet spell in a 4 years old child with underlying Tetralogy of Fallot?
questions.solution:
Tet spells - TOF patients are at risk for episodic hypercyanotic or "tet" spells. Transient near occlusion of the RVOT with profound cyanosis. There is Decreased intensity of the heart murmur during attack (due to the markedly diminished blood flow across the obstruction).

Other options -

  • Precipitating factor- when the infant becomes agitated or upset, setting of pain, fever, anemia, and hypovolemia, as well as after a bowel movement or feeding (or, in older children with uncorrected TOF, after vigorous exercise)
  • They may occur more commonly in the morning and after feeding
  • Clinical feature- hyperpnea (rapid and deep respirations), irritability, inconsolability, and progressively severe cyanosis, Loud pulmonary ejection systolic murmur due to stenotic component of TOF.
  • Recovers on squatting
  • It responds to IV Phenylephrine

Reference: Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics 22nd Edition, Chapter 479, page number:2801

questions.text: What is the Concentration of Sodium in mmol/L in reduced osmolarity WHO oral rehydration solution?
questions.solution:
The low-osmolality WHO ORS containing 75 mEq of sodium, 64 mEq of chloride, 20 mEq of potassium, and 75 mmol of glucose/L, with total osmolarity of 245 mOsm/L, is now the global standard of care and more effective than home fluids.

Reference: Nelson textbook of Pediatrics, 22nd edition, Chapter 387, Page number - 2371

questions.text: The valuable diagnostic feature that differentiate anemia of chronic disorder from Iron deficiency anemia is
questions.solution:
The serum iron level in anemia of chronic disorder is low, but without the increase in total iron-binding capacity (serum transferrin) that occurs in iron deficiency. This pattern of low serum iron and low to normal iron-binding protein (serum transferrin) is a regular and valuable diagnostic feature.

Reference: Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics 22nd Edition, Chapter 500, page number:2935.

questions.text:
An infant is born at 36 weeks gestation. Oligohydramnios has been noted during the latter part of the pregnancy, immediately after birth the Infant has respiratory distress and requires intubation. Additionally, his abdomen is noted to be markedly distended with bilateral palpable masses.
What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The diagnosis of ARPKD is strongly suggested by bilateral palpable flank masses in an infant with pulmonary hypoplasia, oligohydramnios, hypertension, and the absence of renal cysts by sonography.

Other options -

B. Autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease- symptoms usually begin in adulthood with possible cyst formation in multiple organs (liver, pancreas, spleen, brain) and the possible development of saccular cerebral aneurysms.

C. Multicystic dysplastic kidney - usually doesn't cause symptoms and is often discovered during a prenatal ultrasound or physical exam.

D. Wilms tumour - the most common kidney tumor in children. symptoms include blood in the urine, high blood pressure, fever, upset stomach, weight loss, and lack of appetite

Reference: Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics 22nd Edition, Chapter 563, page number :3213

questions.text: A 4-year-old girl present with a 6 months history of recurrent abdominal pain, chronic constipation alternating with loose stools, abdominal distension, and poor weight gain. The patient has a 7-year-old brother who had been diagnosed with hypothyroidism 3 years earlier. You suspect a diagnosis of celiac disease. Which among the following laboratory tests should first be used in the diagnostic approach?
questions.solution:
All these signs and symptoms are of celiac disease, Intestinal symptoms are more common in children whose disease is diagnosed within the first 2 years of life; failure to thrive, chronic diarrhea, vomiting, abdominal distention,muscle wasting, anorexia, and irritability are present in most cases.

Diagnosis of CD is based on a combination of symptoms, antibodies, and duodenal histology. The initial approach to symptomatic patients is to test for anti-TTG IgA antibodies and for total IgA in serum to exclude IgA deficiency.

  • Serological Tests: Blood tests are conducted to check for specific antibodies (e.g., tissue transglutaminase antibodies (tTG-IgA), deamidated gliadin peptide (DGP)). High levels suggest an immune response to gluten.
  • Genetic Testing: HLA-DQ2 and HLA-DQ8 genetic markers can be tested to rule out celiac disease, as these are necessary but not sufficient for its development.
  • Endoscopy with Biopsy: If blood tests are positive, an upper endoscopy is usually performed to obtain small intestine tissue samples. Damage to the villi confirms the diagnosis.

Reference: Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics 22nd Edition, Chapter 384, page number:2329

questions.text: CXR suggestive of which of the following congenital heart disease?
questions.solution:
On radiographic pic, heart size is enlarged, box-shaped cardiomegaly caused by enlargement of the right atrium, totally obscuring the pulmonary fields: s/o Ebstein Anomaly / BOX shaped heart.

  • Ebstein anomaly consists of downward displacement of an abnormal tricuspid valve into the right ventricle.
  • The right ventricle is thus divided into 2 parts by the abnormal tricuspid valve: the first, a thin-walled "atrialized" portion, is continuous with the cavity of the right atrium; the second, often smaller portion consists of normal ventricular myocardium.
  • The right atrium is enlarged as a result of tricuspid valve regurgitation, although the degree is extremely variable.
  • ECG usually shows a right bundle branch block without increased right precordial voltage, normal or tall and broad P waves, and a normal or prolonged P-R interval.

Other options -

  • Option A. Lutembacher syndrome - CXR Findings include pulmonary plethora, left atrial enlargement, right ventricular enlargement, and pulmonary artery enlargement.
  • Option B. Tricuspid atresia - only cyanotic heart disease which has significant left ventricular hypertrophy and left axis deviation on ECG, due to volume overload of Left sided heart.
  • Option C. Scimitar syndrome is associated with anomalous vein resembles a curved sword, or scimitar, that drains the right lung into the systemic venous system.

Reference: Nelson textbook of Pediatrics, 22nd edition, Chapter 479, Page number:2809

questions.text:
Which of the following ECG changes is typically observed in hyperkalemia?
A) Tall R waves
B) Broad QRS complex
C) Tall T-waves
D) ST depression
questions.solution:
ECG changes of hyperkalemia: Changes in the ECG begin with peaking of the T waves, followed by ST-segment depression, an increased PR interval, flattening of the P wave, and widening of the QRS complex.

Reference: Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics, 22nd Edition, Chapter 73, page number: 497.

questions.text: A cyanotic 6 months baby with oligemic lung fields and ECG showing left axis deviation is having which of the following CHD -
questions.solution:
Tricuspid atresia is the only cyanotic heart disease which has significant left ventricular hypertrophy and left axis deviation on ECG, due to volume overload of Left sided heart.

Other options -

A. Tetralogy of Fallot does not cause cyanosis in the neonatal period. Some degree of cyanosis is usually evident at birth, with the extent depending on the degree of limitation to pulmonary blood flow. An increased LV impulse may be noted, in contrast to most other causes of cyanotic heart disease, in which an increased RV impulse is usually present. Most patients have holosystolic murmurs audible along the left sternal border; S2 is usually single.

C. Transposition of great arteries presents with cyanosis, signs of heart failure, murmur and failure to thrive

D. Truncus arteriosus causes complete mixing of systemic and pulmonary venous return at the VSD and truncal valve level leading to moderate cyanosis, pulmonary hypertension and CHF. ECG shows normal QRS axis with biventricular hypertrophy and left atrial enlargement.

Reference: Nelson textbook of pediatrics 22nd edition - Chapter 479, page number:2807

questions.text: A term infant presents with jaundice at day 23 of life. Physical examination reveals hepatomegaly and elevated conjugated bilirubin levels. Which of the following is an uncommon cause of jaundice in this case?
questions.solution:
In this scenario, the term neonate presents with hepatomegaly, and direct hyperbilirubinemia and Crigler-Najjar syndrome is the most uncommon cause of jaundice and it is seen initially on the second or third day.

Crigler-Najjar syndrome or Familial nonhemolytic Icterus is a rare genetic disorder characterized by impaired bilirubin conjugation due to deficient or absent UDP-glucuronosyltransferase enzyme activity. It presents with severe unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia, often requiring phototherapy or exchange transfusion for management.

 Other options -

A. Persistent hemolysis is a common cause of jaundice in neonates and is characterized by indirect hyperbilirubinemia. It is often associated with conditions such as ABO or Rh incompatibility, G6PD deficiency, or hereditary spherocytosis.

B. Breastfeeding jaundice is a common cause of jaundice in the first week of life and is usually due to inadequate breast milk intake leading to decreased bilirubin elimination. It typically resolves with increased breastfeeding frequency and adequate milk intake.

D. Cholestasis refers to impaired bile flow and can be caused by various conditions, including biliary atresia, choledochal cysts, or metabolic disorders. It can present with jaundice, pale stools, and dark urine.

Reference: Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics, 22nd Edition. Chapter 137,page number:1107

questions.text: A 1-year-old child with antenatally detected hydronephrosis undergoes a normal micturating cystourethrogram (MCU). The child is asymptomatic, with stable renal function. Which of the following investigations would be the most appropriate next step?
questions.solution:
The child has antenatally detected hydronephrosis with a normal micturating cystourethrogram (MCU) and is asymptomatic, with stable renal function. The most appropriate next step in the management would be a renal ultrasound. It is a non-invasive imaging modality that provides detailed information about the anatomy and size of the kidneys, the presence of any obstructive lesions, and the degree of hydronephrosis. It is a valuable tool in assessing the progression or resolution of hydronephrosis and guiding further management decisions.

 Other options -

B. A Dimercaptosuccinic acid (DMSA) scan is useful in assessing renal cortical scarring or renal parenchymal defects and is typically performed in cases of urinary tract infection (UTI) or vesicoureteral reflux (VUR).

C. A Diethylenetriamine pentaacetic acid (DTPA) scan is a functional renal scan that evaluates the differential function and drainage of the kidneys. It provides information on the function of each kidney and helps identify any obstructive uropathy or renal scarring.

D. A Voiding cystourethrogram (VCUG) is indicated when there are clinical signs of urinary tract infection (UTI) or suspicion of vesicoureteral reflux (VUR) based on history or other findings.

Reference: Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics, 22nd Edition, Chapter 577, page number:3276.

questions.text: A 12-year-old girl presents with pain in her lower back and easy fatigability. Laboratory investigations reveal normocytic anemia and increased lactate dehydrogenase levels. Imaging studies show diffuse bone marrow involvement. Bone marrow biopsy confirms the diagnosis of acute lymphoblastic leukemia. Which of the following is NOT a common presenting symptom of ALL?
questions.solution:
Acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) is a type of cancer that affects the bone marrow and blood. It commonly presents with a variety of symptoms related to bone marrow infiltration and decreased production of normal blood cells. The most common presenting symptoms of ALL include fatigue, bone pain, and petechiae.

Lymphadenopathy, or enlarged lymph nodes, is not a typical presenting symptom of ALL. Lymph node enlargement is more commonly associated with other conditions such as infections or lymphomas.

Other options -

A. Fatigue is a common symptom in children with ALL and is often related to anemia caused by decreased red blood cell production.

B. Bone pain is another common symptom, often localized to the long bones and caused by the infiltration of leukemic cells into the bone marrow.

C. Petechiae, which are small, pinpoint-sized red or purple spots on the skin or mucous membranes, may occur due to decreased platelet production and abnormal clotting.

Reference: Nelson's Textbook of Pediatrics, 22nd Edition, Chapter 544, page number:3098

questions.text: A 2-year-old child presents with recurrent infections and eczema. Laboratory evaluation reveals a low platelet count and elevated mean platelet volume. Which of the following conditions should be included in the differential diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome is a X-linked primary immunodeficiency disorder characterized by eczema, thrombocytopenia, and recurrent infections. The low platelet count is due to both decreased production and increased destruction of platelets. The elevated MPV is thought to be due to the increased production of large, immature platelets. The immunodeficiency is due to defects in T and B cell function.

Other options -

A. Immune thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP): ITP is an acquired autoimmune disorder characterized by a low platelet count, usually due to platelet destruction by autoantibodies.While ITP can present with thrombocytopenia, it is not typically associated with elevated MPV or immunodeficiency

B. Thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP): TTP is a rare disorder caused by a deficiency in the ADAMTS13 enzyme, leading to the formation of microthrombi and subsequent thrombocytopenia. While TTP can present with thrombocytopenia and elevated MPV, it is not typically associated with eczema or immunodeficiency

C. Bernard-Soulier syndrome: Bernard-Soulier syndrome is a rare inherited bleeding disorder caused by a deficiency in the glycoprotein Ib-IX-V receptor on platelets. It can present with thrombocytopenia and large platelets, but is not typically associated with eczema or immunodeficiency

Reference: Nelson's Textbook of Pediatrics, 22nd Edition, Chapter 533, page number:3052

questions.text: A 9-year-old child is consistently overweight and has a body mass index (BMI) in the 95th percentile for their age and gender. The parents report that the child frequently consumes sugary and high-fat foods and drinks. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The child's BMI in the 95th percentile, along with a diet high in sugary and high-fat foods, suggest obesity.

Obesity, or increased adiposity, is defined using the body mass index, an excellent proxy for more direct measurement of body fat.

BMI = weight in kg/(height in meters)2.

During childhood, levels of body fat change beginning with high adiposity during infancy. Body fat levels decrease for approximately 5.5 years until the period called adiposity rebound, when body fat is typically at the lowest level. Adiposity then increases until early adulthood.

Consequently, obesity and overweight are defined using BMI percentiles for children ≥2 years old and weight/length percentiles for infants <2 years old.

The criterion for obesity is BMI ≥95th percentile, and for overweight is BMI between 85th and 95th percentiles.

Other options -

B. Type 1 diabetes, C. Prader-Willi syndrome, and D. Cushing syndrome can all cause weight gain, but are less likely to be the primary cause of obesity in this scenario.

Reference: Nelson's Textbook of Pediatrics, 22nd Edition, Chapter 65, page number:438
